qas.question: Who were a non-Semitic caucasoid people?
What influences did the Sumerian language seem to retain?
What do archaeological records clearly show about the Sumerian culture?
When were settlements started in southern Mesopotamia?
Why were the lands in the region the Sumerian people settled fertile?

answers.text: silt deposited by the Tigris and the Euphrates rivers

qas.question: What period began in the 53rd century?
Where did people fish in the Ubaid period?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>The Sumerians<b5_0/><a0_0/> were a non-Semitic caucasoid people, and spoke a language isolate; a number of linguists believed they could detect a substrate language beneath Sumerian, because names of some of Sumer's major cities are not Sumerian, revealing influences of <a1_0>earlier inhabitants<a1_0/>. However, the archaeological record shows clear <a2_0>uninterrupted cultural continuity<a2_0/> from the time of the <a3_0>early <b6_0>Ubaid period<b6_0/><a3_0/> (5300 – 4700 BC C-14) settlements in southern Mesopotamia. The Sumerian people who settled here farmed the lands in this region that were made fertile by <a4_0>silt deposited by the <b7_0>Tigris and the Euphrates rivers<b7_0/><a4_0/>.
